Description: Body fragment of East Greek pottery open vase; interior glazed with two red bands lined in white preserved; exterior, from top: small part of upper frieze: left-facing key meander frieze between bands with added red and white lines; frieze of wild goats to the right (preserved are the horn of one and the hindquarters of another); added red on the haunch of the left goat.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Edgar, in his catalogue of Greek vases from the Cairo Museum, compares the sherd to ones discussed in Gardner 1886, p. 41, B, b.1, which discusses large bowls that resemble Naukratite vases in decoration. One example, mentioned in Gardner 1886 (pl. VII, no. 5) is not Naukratite.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 244, no. 258)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 26)
Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 14, no. 41, pl. 10)
Edgar 1911 / Catalogue Générale des antiquités égyptiennes du musée du Caire, Greek Vases (p. 13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.1106)
